body:
I think I'm okay with removing it as long as the documentation suggests some good default so people aren't left guessing.

> I thought if maybe in the future we could do something to make it more accurate... but it hasn't happened in the past 5 years so I guess it wouldn't be happening any time soon.

I agree.  On kqueue-based systems we know how much data is available (it's in `ev->data` and we record it as `w->rcount`) but we don't act on it because by the time we process it more data may be available, necessitating more system calls to drain the kernel buffer.
It was discussed that on linux ioctl FIONREAD was too much overhead for no benefit. Ram is cheap, allocating enough of a buffer in userspace is good enough.

issue.title: Improve documentation
issue.body:
Some  people (even seasoned developers) get thrown off by our documentation, let's try to fix that!
- [ ] Add descriptions of what each funcion does, aside from linking the man page
- [ ] Add an example for each handle at the top of its file, and for the individual function after their description
- [ ] Add a "getting started" section
- [ ] Document parameters and possible return values for all functions (the UDP docs are a good example though it can still be improved further)
- [ ] Evaluate our relationship with the uvbook: see if we can collaborate somehow, in case we want to add parts of it to our docs
- [ ] Find a Sphinx theme (or adapt an existing one) to be mobile friendly: https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues/801
- [ ] Add some more examples: a simple HTTP client which sends "hello" using http_parser, a "micro netcat", (other suggestions are welcome)

This is an ongoing effort, those who want to contribute to it are welcome to do so, please leave a note here so we know who is working on what.  Modifying each handle separately is probably the best, to be gin with, and the individual functions in batches.

Hi there, 

I'm still getting familiar with the codebase etc. I just wanted to make sure I'm on the right path.

Thus far I've [removed](https://github.com/jessicaquynh/libuv/commit/94bc9caa5b15dc39d9d67ab17618719c6e69ff59) `suggested_size` from the typedef. And I'm working on removing the parameter from the `src` and `tests`; but I am encountering allocation failures on the tests where I've replaced the suggested size with 65536. 

Perhaps it's not as simple as this implementation. If anyone can shed light on this, I'd very much appreciate it.
@jessicaquynh Can you define "allocation failures" or give an example of where it's failing for you now?

Yes certainly.

This is one error output from `test-ping-pong.c`:

```
not ok 42 - tcp_ping_pong

Output from process `tcp_ping_pong`:

```

Similar error output occurs for the tests `tcp_ping_pong_v6` and `pipe_ping_pong`.

My definition of an allocation failure (fairly vague, I apologize) was the error output `object X: pointer being freed was not allocated`. There are only 3 tests that fail, and this is the shared error between them.
That message suggests you introduced a bug somewhere.  Perhaps round up your current work-in-progress and open a pull request so others can help you look at it.

issue.title: v2: remove suggested_size from alloc_cb
issue.body:
This PR is opened for issue #1025. It removes the parameter from the
`typedef`in the the allocation callback and subsequent implementations.

It has been relatively underused, and users are able to allocate 
as much data as they want. The suggested size is now contained 
in the documentation for users to have a good default to go to.

body: Thanks @bnoordhuis, I have taken your recommendation and opened a [pull request](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/pull/1114). I look forward to any feedback!

I suggest to pause this for a while.

The reason the suggested_size is not used is mainly because it is not required on streams, but it is required on message-based communication.

I implemented a length-prefixed message framing for libuv with an alloc_cb in which the suggested_size must be respected, at least as the minimum size.

Even if this message framing code is not integrated in libuv but used on top of it, it would be good to keep the alloc_db in this way so it will remain compatible with implementations that require a suggested_size on the allocation.

@kroggen 

> I suggest to pause this for a while.
> 
> The reason the suggested_size is not used is mainly because it is not required on streams, but it is required on message-based communication.
> 
> I implemented a length-prefixed message framing for libuv with an alloc_cb in which the suggested_size must be respected, at least as the minimum size.

The suggested size can still be picked by you, currently libuv suggests a hardcoded value, which doesn't give us much.  libuv won't do anything with that suggested size, it will use the size for the buffer you initialized, be that larger or smaller than the suggested one.

> Even if this message framing code is not integrated in libuv but used on top of it, it would be good to keep the alloc_db in this way so it will remain compatible with implementations that require a suggested_size on the allocation.

The API change is minimal, it will happen in a *major* release, and you'll be able to easily ifdef it.  We'll have migration documentation, when time comes.
